awd_titl_txt: Elements: Software: Towards Efficient Embedded Data Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
Embedded databases are ubiquitous, though that fact may not be widely-recognized. Every smart phone has many embedded databases, which implies that billions of people worldwide carry dozens of databases in their phones/pockets every day. Many of these databases are powered by data processing technology that has not kept up with the pace with which the underling hardware in phones have evolved. As a result, data processing is slow, and consumes more energy than needed. The focus of this proposal is on developing new data processing technology for mobile devices that targets a 10X efficiency and performance improvements. The aims of the project go beyond more efficient data processing on phones to also include more efficient processing in embedded environments, which also includes databases running on laptops. Thus, the project aims for a broad impact on database across a spectrum of mobile devices.

The technical contributions of this project are in recognizing that modern hardware, even at the ?low-end? which includes mobile phones and laptops, now have multiple processing cores, relatively large amounts of memory, and flash storage. There is a critical need for a new class of embedded data processing systems that can work efficiently, and effectively on such modern mobile platforms. This project aims to build a system, called Hustle, to address this need. The project will design, develop and implement a range of data processing methods, which include predicate-based concurrency control mechanisms, query processing methods that inherently expose and exploit opportunities for intra and inter-operator parallelism, and query optimization methods that target embedded settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Database systems are ubiquitous, even if they are not directly noticeable by end users. For example, SQLite3 is the most deployed embedded database system, with many billions of installations worldwide. Most cell phone users have multiple SQLite3 instances running on their phones, as this data platform is often used as the data management layer by applications. Thus, methods to improve the performance of SQLite3 have a profound impact, as higher performance means a better user experience and higher energy efficiency (resulting in longer battery life on mobile devices). This project evaluated various data processing techniques that leverage modern hardware to improve the performance of data platforms, especially in embedded settings. Several prototypes were created to enhance SQLite3, and one of them was found to be particularly suitable. This method uses a technique called Lookahead Information Passing, in which the query used by the data platform is analyzed to create a summary structure on-the-fly, resulting in less data being moved around when the query is evaluated, thus leading to higher performance and lower energy consumption. The methods were tested on several conventional processors, including Intel processors and Raspberry Pi. The results showed significant improvement for analytic queries (over 4X in some cases). The code for this work was released as open source to the SQLite3 team, who then incorporated the changes into the main SQLite3 platform in February 2022. Given the popularity of SQLite3, this code is now running on devices across the planet, improving the performance of applications in a diverse set of areas.
